title: Rama Alhariri
text: The data is obtained from the Patient Risk Profiles dataset in TidyTuesday package. It specifically examines patient risk on 14 outcomes based on medical history features. The data dictionary can be found here.

title: Rama Alhariri
text: The data is obtained from the Patient Risk Profiles dataset in TidyTuesday package. It specifically examines patient risk on 14 outcomes based on medical history features. The data dictionary can be found here.

title: Rama Alhariri
text:
Questions
What is the prevalence and distribution of pulmonary embolism stratified by sex and smoking status?
How does the risk of developing pulmonary embolism correlate with the risk of developing 13 other health outcomes?





Diagram depicting pulmonary embolism

title: Rama Alhariri
text:
Audience
The intended audience for this dataset is healthcare professionals, researchers, or organizations involved in the healthcare industry. This type of dataset could be used to analyze and assess the risk factors associated with patientsâ€™ health conditions. Healthcare providers, insurers, researchers, and policymakers may be interested in such data to understand patterns, make informed decisions, and improve patient outcomes.

title: Rama Alhariri
text:
Reading in libraries


Show the code
library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)
library(stringr)
library(here)
library(ggplot2)
library(forcats)

title: Rama Alhariri
text:
Reading in Data






Note



My data was obtained from the Patient Risk Profiles dataset on TidyTuesday. Two options exist to load the dataset, the first one is through using the TidyTuesday R package and the second one is through accessing the .csv file on github



Option 1: TidyTuesday


Show the code
# if(!file.exists(here("data","tuesdata_rainfall.RDS"))){

#   rainfall <- tuesdata$rainfall
#   temperature <- tuesdata$temperature
#   
#   # save the files to RDS objects
#   saveRDS(tuesdata$rainfall, file = here("data","tuesdata_rainfall.RDS"))
#   saveRDS(tuesdata$temperature, file = here("data","tuesdata_temperature.RDS"))
# }
#

Option 2: Reading from GitHub


Show the code
# Option 2: Read directly from GitHub

patient_risk_profiles <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2023/2023-10-24/patient_risk_profiles.csv', show_col_types = FALSE)

title: Rama Alhariri
text:
Tidying the data






Note



Notice below that I have about 100 columns, some of which can be re-sorted into a long format, particularly to ease downstream graphical manipulation. I like to personally make my dataframes long when inputting data to graph on ggplot.




Show the code
colnames(patient_risk_profiles)

Code to make my data long
patient_risk_profiles_renamed=patient_risk_profiles %>% 
  rename(Female = `Sex = FEMALE`,
         Male = `Sex = MALE`,
         `0-4` = `age group:   0 -   4`,
         `5-9` = `age group:   5 -   9`,
        `10-14` = `age group:  10 -  14`,
        `15-19` = `age group:  15 -  19`,
        `20-24` = `age group:  20 -  24`,
        `25-29` = `age group:  25 -  29`,
        `30-34` = `age group:  30 -  34`,
        `35-39` = `age group:  35 -  39`,
        `40-44` = `age group:  40 -  44`,
        `45-49` = `age group:  45 -  49`,
        `50-54` = `age group:  50 -  54`,
        `55-59` = `age group:  55 -  59`,
        `60-64` = `age group:  60 -  64`,
        `65-69` = `age group:  65 -  69`,
        `70-74` = `age group:  70 -  74`,
        `75-79` = `age group:  75 -  79`,
        `80-84` = `age group:  80 -  84`,
        `85-89` = `age group:  85 -  89`,
        `90-94` = `age group:  90 -  94`,
        `Risk of Pulmonary Embolism` = 
          `predicted risk of Pulmonary Embolism`) %>% 
  mutate(Sex = ifelse(Female==1, "Female", 
                      ifelse(Male==1, "Male", "unkown")),
         `Age Group` = case_when(
           `0-4` == 1 ~ "0-4",
           `5-9` == 1 ~ "5-9",
           `10-14` == 1 ~ "10-14",
           `15-19` == 1 ~ "15-19",
           `20-24` == 1 ~ "20-24",
           `25-29` == 1 ~ "25-29",
           `30-34` == 1 ~ "30-34",
           `35-39` == 1 ~ "35-39",
           `40-44` == 1 ~ "40-44",
           `45-49` == 1 ~ "45-49",
           `50-54` == 1 ~ "50-54",
           `55-59` == 1 ~ "55-59",
           `60-64` == 1 ~ "60-64",
           `65-69` == 1 ~ "65-69",
           `70-74` == 1 ~ "70-74",
           `75-79` == 1 ~ "75-79",
           `80-84` == 1 ~ "80-84",
           `85-89` == 1 ~ "85-89",
           `90-94` == 1 ~ "90-94",
           TRUE ~ "Unknown"
    )) %>% 
  pivot_longer(
    cols=starts_with("predicted risk"),
    names_to = "predicted_risk",
    values_to = "risk_value") %>% 
  mutate(predicted_risk = str_remove(predicted_risk, 
                                     "predicted risk of ")) %>%
  mutate(predicted_risk = fct_recode(predicted_risk,
        "Acute pancreatitis" = 
          "Acute pancreatitis, with No chronic or hereditary or common causes of pancreatitis",
        "Parkinson's Disease" = 
          "Parkinson's disease, inpatient or with 2nd diagnosis",
        "Sudden Hearing Loss" = 
          "Sudden Hearing Loss, No congenital anomaly or middle or inner ear conditions",
        "Sudden Vision Loss" = 
          "Sudden Vision Loss, with no eye pathology causes"))

title: Rama Alhariri
section: Prevalence of pulmonary embolism by sex
text:
Prevalence of pulmonary embolism by sex


Show the code
patient_risk_profiles_renamed %>% 
  group_by(Sex) %>% 
  summarize(mean=mean(`Risk of Pulmonary Embolism`)) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x=`Sex`, 
             y=mean)) +
  geom_bar(stat="identity") + 
  labs(title="Prevalence of Pulmonary Embolism by Sex",
       subtitle=str_wrap("Males have higher average predicted risk of pulmonary embolism")) +
  xlab("Sex")+ 
  ylab("Mean Predicted Risk of Pulmonary Embolism")











Warning



We cannot say this is a statistically significant difference without carrying out a t-test. This is merely a rough illustration.

title: Rama Alhariri
section: Distribution of Predicted Risk of Pulmonary Embolism Stratified by Smoking Status
text:
Distribution of Predicted Risk of Pulmonary Embolism Stratified by Smoking Status


Show the code
patient_risk_profiles_renamed %>% 
ggplot(aes(x=`Risk of Pulmonary Embolism`, 
           color=as.factor(`Smoking in prior year`))) +
  geom_density() +
  labs(title=str_wrap("Distribution of Predicted Risk of Pulmonary Embolism Stratified by Smoking Status"),
       subtitle = str_wrap("There is a lower predicted risk of pulmonary embolism for non-smokers compared to smokers")) +
  ylab("Density") + 
  scale_color_discrete(name = "Smoking Status", 
                      labels = c("Non-smoker", "Smoker"))

title: Rama Alhariri
text:
Mean predicted risk


Show the code
patient_risk_profiles_renamed %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x=`Risk of Pulmonary Embolism`, 
             y=`risk_value`,
             color=`Sex`)) +
  geom_point() +
  facet_wrap(~predicted_risk) +
  labs(title=str_wrap("Correlation between the Predicted risks of Different Conditions and Pulmonary Embolism"),
       subtitle = str_wrap("The predicted risk of pulmonary embolism correlates poorly with the predicted risks of other conditions, with the exception of muscle weakness and dementia")) +
  ylab("Predicted Risks") + 
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, vjust = 0.5, hjust=1))

title: Rama Alhariri
text: Hello! My name is Rama Alhariri. I am a PhD student at the Human Genetics and Genomics Program at Johns Hopkins University. I am Syrian-American, though I would not delimit myself to that cultural description as I have lived in and moved around lots of places between Kentucky, Saudi Arabia, Dubai, New York, Shanghai (only for a month) and Baltimore. Some things I like to do for fun involve snuggling with my cat (she is a cuddle bug), hiking, reading, exercising and hanging out with friends and meeting new people.

title: Rama Alhariri
text:
Education
Johns Hopkins University | Baltimore, MD
PhD in Human Genetics and Genomics | August 2021 - Present
New York University Abu Dhabi | Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates
B.A in Biology | September 2017 - June 2021

title: About
text: I am a third year PhD student in the Human Genetics and Genomics program at the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine. As a scientist that grew up most of my life in the Middle East, specifically Dubai, in which I studied and lived with friends from countries all around the world, I have been instilled with a love for ensuring that the scientific work I carry out is inclusive of individuals from underrepresented and understudied backgrounds. While I have and continue to work primarily in the field of genetic epidemiology, I also have an interest in medical genetics as it relates to clinical Mendelian cases. My interest lies mainly in academia, but I also wish to devote time to science education and advocacy - particulary as it relates to capacity building and informed decision making for individuals from underrepresented groups, ensuring that we build partnerships with local communities who feel heard and represented in science.
